questions.text: Q. Match the following: 1. Randomisation a. Eliminates only the known confounders. 2. Standardisation b. Eliminate the effect of age and gender. 3. Restriction c. Eliminates both known and unknown confounders. 4. Matching d. Limits the participation in the study to individuals who are similar concerning confounders.
questions.explanation:
Techniques To Eliminate Confounders

Method

Description

Examples

Matching


 
  • Cases are matched with the control and should be similar to the control in every possible variable that can affect the study's outcome except the disease in question.
  • Done in a case-control study.
  • Eliminates only the known confounders.

In a study on the effect of a new teaching method, students are matched based on their prior academic performance and then assigned to different groups.

Restriction
  • Limits participation in the study to individuals who are similar in terms of confounders.

In a study, Restricting the study to only non-smokers will eliminate the effect of smoking.

Randomisation
  • The technique where every participant will get an equal and known chance of being allocated to either the treatment group or the control group.
  • Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.

In a clinical trial, patients are randomly assigned to receive either a new drug or a placebo, balancing out confounding variables.

Stratification (Segregate)
  • Stratify the participants of the study or segregate them.

In a clinical trial, to eliminate the effect of smoking as a confounder, one can further stratify or segregate participants into smokers and non-smokers.

Standardisation
  • Adjusting the results to a standard population to control for confounding variables often used in rate comparisons
  • Eliminate or control the effect of age and gender.

In a study comparing mortality rates between two countries, rates are standardised to a common age distribution to control for age differences.

Multivariate regression models
  • Used when there are multiple confounders.

In an observational diet and heart disease study, a regression model is used to adjust for age, gender, and physical activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is found unresponsive and without a pulse. Emergency responders are activated, and advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols are initiated. Which of the following steps should be prioritized immediately after confirming cardiac arrest?

options.label: B
options.text: Ensure proper airway management using bag-mask ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate high-quality chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate high-quality chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

1. Early Recognition and Activation

Identify cardiac arrest signs quickly and alert emergency services.

2. High-Quality Chest Compressions (Option C)

Initiate compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, with a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm) for adults, allowing full chest recoil.

3. Early Defibrillation (Option D ruled out)

Deploy an AED promptly; follow prompts for defibrillation if a shockable rhythm is present.

4. Airway Management (Option B ruled out)

Ensure airway patency using techniques like bag-mask ventilation or advanced airway placement; provide oxygen to support ventilation.

5. Drug Administration (Option A ruled out)

Administer epinephrine (1 mg every 3-5 minutes); consider antiarrhythmics like amiodarone for shock-resistant VF/pulseless VT.

6. Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Assess for reversible causes ("H's and T's"):

Hypoxia

Hypovolemia

Acidosis (Hydrogen ion)

Hyper/hypokalemia

Hypothermia

Tension pneumothorax

Cardiac tamponade

Toxins

Thrombosis (pulmonary/coronary)

7. Post-Resuscitation Care

Provide comprehensive care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), including monitoring and supportive therapies.

8. Continuous Quality Improvement

Assess and enhance resuscitation efforts, focusing on minimizing interruptions in compressions and following protocols.

options.text: It is made of polyurethane foam and saturated with a spermicide nonoxynol-9

options.label: B
options.text: It must be left in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse.

questions.explanation:
Brand name

TODAY

Material

Small polyurethane foam sponge

Mechanism of action

Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’ (Option A)

Technique of use
  • Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion
  • Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective
  • Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation (Option B)
  • All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today)

Disadvantages
  • No protection from HIV or STDs (Option C)
  • May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours
  • Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation
  • Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI
  • Higher failure rate than diaphragm

Failure rate

Parous women: 20-40 per HWY

Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

A 35-year-old patient undergoes spinal surgery. Postoperatively, he develops a cerebrospinal fluid leak. Which space is most likely compromised?
questions.explanation:
Epidural Space (Option A)

Subdural Space

Subarachnoid Space
  • Located between the spinal dura mater and the periosteum.
  • Contains:
    • Loose areolar tissue
    • Semiliquid fat
    • Spinal arteries supplying deeper structures
    • Internal vertebral venous plexus.
  • Epidural anesthesia is given here
  • Potential space between the dura and arachnoid mater. (Option B)
  • Contains a thin layer of serous fluid.
  • Allows movement of the dura over the arachnoid.
  • Extends onto spinal nerves and connects with lymphatic spaces.
  • Wide space between pia mater and arachnoid mater.
  • Filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). (Option C)
  • Cushions the brain and spinal cord.
  • Wider in the spinal region, especially below the spinal cord where it encloses the cauda equina.
  • Lumbar punctures are typically performed between L3 & L4 vertebrae.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the trench method of refuse disposal in sanitary landfills?

options.label: A
options.text: The trench method involves digging a trench, burying solid waste in it, and covering it with soil.

options.label: B
options.text: The trench method entails digging a trench, filling it with refuse and covering it with a layer of supplemental earth from outside sources to manage waste.

options.label: C
options.text: Decomposition begins as refuse heats to 60°C within 4-6 weeks, killing pathogens.

options.label: D
options.text: Refuse cools immediately after burial, starts decomposition at ambient temperature, and rises to 60°C after 2-3 months.

questions.correct_answer: A. The trench method involves digging a trench, burying solid waste in it, and covering it with soil.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a swelling on his left tibia. An X-ray of the leg shows a destructive process with indistinct borders and an onion-skin pattern of the periosteal bone. A biopsy was performed, as shown in the image below. Identify the true statements regarding this condition. It is a malignant tumour characterised by primitive round cells with obvious differentiation. It affects boys more than girls. More than 90% of the cases are caused due to t(11;22)(q24;q12) mutation. The presence of rounded cell clusters with a central fibrillary core indicates neuroectodermal differentiation. Chemotherapy-induced necrosis is a negative prognostic indicator.

A 45 y/o male with a history of HIV infection presents to the ED with headache, fever, photophobia, and neck stiffness. His CD4 count is 80 cells/mm³. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein levels. India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid showed the following picture. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Causes
  • Cryptococcus neoformans (most common)
  • Candida
  • Histoplasma
  • Blastomyces
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

Risk factors

Immunocompromised patients

Clinical features
  • Headache
  • Altered mental status, lethargy
  • Fever
  • Neck stiffness
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Investigations
  • Lumbar Puncture: Low glucose and high protein levels. White cell count can be normal or higher than 20 microL and have a lymphocyte predominance.
  • India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells.
  • CSF ELISA for CRAG (Cryptococcal Antigen).

Treatment

(Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with chronic, progressive pelvic pain for the past three years and a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the hospital with lethargy and giddiness. He has a history of being bullied at school due to his physical appearance, which led him to become increasingly interested in various forms of exercise. Over the past three months, he has lost 24 kilograms due to exercise. An ECG performed upon admission is shown below. He appears cachectic and pale. He is assessed by a dietitian and started on nutritional supplements. Two days later, the patient exhibits involuntary muscle contractions, followed by periods of unresponsiveness and confusion. Which electrolyte abnormality would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Risk Factors
  • Severe malnutrition (e.g., anorexia nervosa, prolonged fasting)
  • Patients who have experienced significant weight loss or are undergoing aggressive refeeding

Metabolic Changes (Option B, C)

Increased insulin levels lead to shifts in electrolytes, particularly:

  • Decreased phosphate (PO4³⁻): Essential for energy production and cellular function. Most common electrolyte abnormality seen in this condition; it is accompanied by prolonged QT interval and bradycardia.
  • Decreased potassium (K⁺): Important for cardiac and muscular function.
  • Decreased magnesium (Mg²⁺): Critical for many biochemical reactions and muscle function.

Clinical Complications
  • Cardiac complications: Arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances.
  • Rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown caused by electrolyte disturbances and increased workload.
  • Seizures: Can occur due to severe electrolyte imbalances.

Management

To prevent refeeding syndrome, it is crucial to:

  • Start feeding at a reduced caloric rate and gradually increase.
  • Monitor electrolytes closely, particularly phosphate, potassium, and magnesium.
  • Provide thiamine supplementation before correcting glucose levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with symptoms of muscle weakness, fasciculations, and myotonic jerks. The patient has a history of smoking and has been taking a cholinesterase inhibitor for a recent injury.   • CNS: site specific excitation or inhibition

Nature

Has Intrinsic ion channel, pentamer of 𝛂2 , 𝜷, 𝛾 or 𝝴 and 𝜹 subunits

Has intrinsic ion channel, pentamer of only 𝛂 or 𝛂𝜷 subunits

Transducer mechanism

Opening of cation (Na+ K+) channels

Opening of cation (Na+, K+, Ca2+) channels

Agonists

Phenyl trimethyl ammonium (PTMA), Nicotine

Dimethylphenylpiperazinium (DMPP), Nicotine

Antagonists

Tubocurarine, 𝛂-Bungarotoxin, Atracurium, Vecuronium

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, pallor and decreased urine output for the past three days. She reports a recent history of diarrhoea that started and has now resolved. Physical examination reveals pallor, mild jaundice, and petechiae on the lower limbs. Laboratory studies show haemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL, platelet count of 35,000/mm³, elevated serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL, and LDH of 950 U/L.A peripheral blood smear reveals schistocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Types

Description

Typical HUS/ D+HUS
  • Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), called typical HUS, is the most common cause of HUS.
  • Escherichia coli 0157:H7 (E coli 0157:H7) has been linked to typical HUS.
  • Typical HUS comprises 90% to 95% of HUS.
  • Commonly arises from consuming contaminated food or drink and through person-to-person contact.
  • It has low morbidity compared to atypical HUS.

Atypical HUS/

D-HUS
  • The cause of aHUS is the abnormal activation of the alternative complement pathway.
  • The alternative complement pathway is activated with particular emphasis on regulatory Factor H, stabilises C3, and inactivates C3b.

Secondary HUS
  • HUS secondary to underlying conditions or infections, commonly presenting as aHUS with abnormal complement system activation.
  • The most significant component of this category is HUS caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Caused by Inherited vitamin B12 metabolism disorder, HIV, influenza virus and malignant hypertension.

questions.text: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?

During a forensic examination of a shooting incident, a medical examiner discovers both shotgun pellets and rifle bullets at the crime scene. The examiner notes the differences in their design and function. Which statement about these ammunition types is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Shotgun cartridges contain multiple projectiles that spread upon firing.

options.label: B
options.text: Wads are used in all types of cartridges

options.label: C
options.text: Rifle bullets are generally elongated with a pointed tip

options.label: D
options.text: Rifle bullets and shotgun pellets are made of lead

questions.correct_answer: B. Wads are used in all types of cartridges
questions.explanation:
Cartridge of Rifle

Cartridge of Shotgun
  • Contains a primer on the base and a cartridge case filled with gunpowder.
  • Features a single projectile (bullet).
  • Does not include a wad (Option B)
  • Contains lead shots (Option D)/Pellets (Multiple Projectiles) (Option A)
  • Wads: Used only in smoothbore weapons (Shotguns).
  • Advantages of Wads:
    • Facilitates optimal pressure.
    • Prevents gas escape from the bore.
    • Aids in lubrication.
    • Stops gas from escaping at the breech end.
    • Maintains separation between the propellant and projectiles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

There is also a rise in JVP during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35 y/o woman presents with an incidental liver mass found on ultrasound. Further imaging with CT and MRI is performed, revealing a well-defined mass with a central scar which is hyperintense on T2w MRI. The lesion shows hot spot on sulphur colloid scan. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Feature

FNH

FLC

Ultrasound

It is difficult to detect as it has similar reflectivity to the liver.

Solid, hyperechoic lesions, central scar and calcification may be seen

CT

Well-defined lobulated mass, isoattenuating to liver parenchyma; marked homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase with a central low-attenuation scar, mass effect visible. (Option C)

Well-defined mass, often hyperattenuating; may enhance the arterial phase  (Option D ruled out)

MRI

Isointense on T1, hyperintense on T2; central scar hypointense on T1

Hyperintense on T1 if fat-containing, significant enhancement on arterial phase.

Key Differentiator

Central stellate scar: Enhances on CT/MRI; no calcification

Scar+ , calcification  more common

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. On examination, he has a large nasopharyngeal mass with invasion into the surrounding bony structures and involvement of the intracranial space. Imaging studies reveal multiple lymph nodes in the neck, some of which are greater than 6 cm in size. There is no evidence of distant metastasis . What is the TNM staging of this cancer?
questions.explanation:
Category

Stage

Description

Primary Tumour (T)

T1

Tumour confined to the nasopharynx

T2

Tumour extends to soft tissues of the oropharynx and/or nasal cavity

T3

Tumour invades bony structures and/or paranasal sinuses

T4

Tumour with intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx, orbit, or masticator space

Regional Lymph Nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Unilateral metastasis in lymph node(s), ≤6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa

N2

Bilateral metastasis in lymph nodes, ≤6 cm in greatest dimension, above the supraclavicular fossa

N3a

Metastasis greater than 6 cm in lymph node(s)

N3b

Metastasis in lymph node(s) in the supraclavicular fossa

Distant Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A 35-year-old teacher complains of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and a weak voice, especially after prolonged speaking. Laryngoscopic examination reveals keyhole appearance of the glottis during phonation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Phonasthenia

Puberphonia

(Option A)

Functional Aphonia

(Option C)

Hysteric Aphonia

(Option D)

Definition

Vocal fatigue due to weakness in the thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles causing vocal cord bowing

Mutational falsetto with persistent high-pitched voice after puberty, more common in males

Psychogenic voice disorder with loss of voluntary voice despite normal vocal cord structure

Conversion disorder with sudden voice loss due to psychological stress

Features
  • Weak, fatigued voice after speaking
  • Keyhole appearance of the glottis from vocal cord bowing
  • High-pitched voice not congruent with age or gender
  • Thin, weak voice quality
  • No structural abnormalities in the larynx or vocal cords
  • Inability to produce voice voluntarily
  • Able to cough or whisper, indicating normal vocal cord function
  • Sudden inability to speak after emotional distress
  • No organic pathology affecting the larynx

Laryngoscopic Findings

Keyhole appearance of the glottis from vocal cord bowing

False vocal cord hypertrophy

Vocal cords do not fully adduct during phonation but work normally during reflexive actions like coughing

Vocal cords appear normal but may not come together during speech attempts. Patients can cough or whisper

Management
  • Voice therapy to strengthen vocal muscles
  • Thyroplasty for severe cases
  • Voice Therapy: pitch adjustment through vocal techniques with a speech therapist.
  • Type III Thyroplasty: Surgery to lower pitch by altering vocal cord tension.

Counseling and voice therapy

Psychological support and speech therapy

questions.text: Choose the correct statements from the following: a)BCG vaccine for TB- primary b)BCG for Ca bladder- secondary c)OCP for contraception- primary d)OCP for PCOD- secondary
questions.explanation:
Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations (statement a)
  • Health education
  • Family planning (statement c)
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examination

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening
  • DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.
  • Treatment (statement b and d )

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not the content of carotid sheath?
questions.explanation:
Contents
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve.

Anatomical Details
  • The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries.
  • The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels.

Anteriorly

The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia.

Posteriorly

The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in the upper arm. Imaging shows that the mass is located deep in the fascia, and biopsy results indicate poorly differentiated pleomorphic cells with high mitotic activity. What is the most important prognostic factor for this patient's soft tissue sarcoma?
questions.explanation:
Prognostic Factor

Importance

Histological Grade

Comprehensive assessment of tumour aggressiveness;

Depth of Tumor

Tumours deep into the fascia are more likely to be malignant and have a poorer prognosis. (Option C)

Size of Tumor

Larger tumours (>5 cm) are more likely to be malignant and associated with a worse prognosis. (Option A)

Presence of Necrosis

Indicates high-grade tumours with aggressive behaviour. (Option B)

Vascular Invasion

Associated with a higher risk of metastasis and worse prognosis

Perineural Invasion

Suggests aggressive behaviour and the potential for local spread

Positive Resection Margins

Higher risk of recurrence if cancer cells remain at the edges of surgical resection

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is known case of chronic stable angina and has undergone PCI with stenting last year. Today morning she presents to ER with a 60-minute episode of chest discomfort that occurred while she was watching television. She describes the pain as a tightness in his chest, radiating to her left arm. She has a history of T2DM and has deranged lipid profile. An ECG reveals inverted T-waves. Which of the following is best next step in managment of this patient?

options.label: B

questions.text: Based on the image provided, which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Measure from the acromion to the olecranon and mark the midpoint.

options.label: B
options.text: MUAC assesses the nutritional status of children aged three months to five years.

options.label: C
options.text: In Shakir’s tape, the Yellow zone indicates 11.5 to 13.5 cm.

options.label: D
options.text: In Shakir’s tape, the Green zone indicates >11.5 cm.

questions.correct_answer: A. Measure from the acromion to the olecranon and mark the midpoint.
questions.explanation:
MID UPPER ARM CIRCUMFERENCE (MUAC)

Definition
  • MUAC is a vital measurement used primarily to assess the nutritional status of children aged 6 months to 5 years. (Option B)
  • Quick and effective screening tool.
  • In infants under 6 months old, the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is not utilized as a measurement criterion. (G88)

Procedure
  • Ensure the child is standing straight with their left arm free of clothing. The arm should be bent at a right angle.
  • Measure the distance between the tip of the shoulder (acromion) and the tip of the elbow (olecranon). Mark the midpoint on the upper arm. (Option A)
  • The child's arm should hang relaxed by their side, with the palm facing the thigh.
  • Use a MUAC tape to wrap around the marked midpoint of the arm. The tape should be snug but not tight enough to pinch the skin.
  • Record the measurement at the zero mark of the tape.

Shakir’s Tape

Shakir's tape is a specific type of MUAC measuring tape designed for use in assessing malnutrition.

It is typically three colour-coded to facilitate easy interpretation of nutritional status. The tape is marked with different zones that correspond to various levels of malnutrition:

  • Red Zone: Indicates severe malnutrition (MUAC < 11.5 cm).
  • Yellow Zone: Indicates moderate malnutrition (MUAC between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm). (Option C)
  • Green Zone: Indicates healthy nutritional status (MUAC > 12.5 cm) (Option D)
 

SHAKIR’S TAPE

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his tidal volume is 400 mL. The dead space is estimated to be 150 mL. Which of the following statements about ventilation and perfusion is/are correct? 1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange. 2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4L/min. 3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4L/min. 4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.
questions.explanation:
Statement

Description

Explanation

1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = TV x RR;

Alveolar ventilation = (TV - Dead Space) x RR.

2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4 L/min.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = 400 mL x 16 = 6.4 L/min.

3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4 L/min.

Correct

Alveolar ventilation = (400 mL - 150 mL) x 16 = 4.0 L/min.

4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.

Correct

Perfusion is typically equal to the cardiac output of the right ventricle, approximately 5.4 L/min.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with BP of 170/110 mmHg and proteinuria. She is stable without evidence of end-organ damage. According to the algorithm for managing severe preeclampsia, what is the recommended management approach?

options.label: B
options.text: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre

options.label: C
options.text: Monitor closely for 24 hours and discharge

options.label: D
options.text: Administer antenatal corticosteroids and terminate pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre
questions.explanation:
Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation
  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management
  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management
  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation. 

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia
  • Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management
  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

questions.text: What is the image given below used for?
questions.correct_answer: A. Local distribution of a disease
questions.explanation:
International variation

Comparisons of disease incidence, prevalence, and patterns between different countries.

National variation

Study disease patterns within a single country, observing differences across regions or states.

Rural-urban variation

Comparisons of disease incidence and prevalence between rural and urban areas within a country.

Local distribution

Detailed examination of disease patterns within small areas, such as specific neighbourhoods or districts.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who recently joined the radiology department was instructed to wear the device shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Assess the amount of radiation exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Should be sent for dose monitoring every 3 months

options.label: D
options.text: It is worn over the lead apron

questions.correct_answer: D. It is worn over the lead apron
questions.explanation:
TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure. (Option C)

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals: (Option B)

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide
Principle

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with a 3-day history of high fever. On the fourth day, the fever abruptly subsided, and the child developed a rash as given in the image. Oral examination revealed ulcers and small red papules at uvulopalatoglossal junction as shown. What are these called?
questions.explanation:
Koplik Spots (Option A) are small, bluish-white spots with a red halo located on the buccal mucosa at the level of premolars and are diagnostic for measles (Rubeola).

Forchheimer spots (Option C) are small reddish spots on the soft palate or uvula, indicative of rubella (German measles).

  

Café au Lait Spots (Option D) are light brown skin patches with irregular borders, often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text: A 35 year old female comes to OPD complaining of being unable to conceive for 3 years. She is a known case of PCOS. Which of the following drugs will you recommend?

A 30-year-old runner complains of difficulty flexing his knee after long-distance running. He reports that once his knee locks in an extended position, it takes effort to initiate flexion again. On examination, you notice that the patient struggles to begin flexion from full extension. Which muscle is likely impaired?
questions.explanation:
Action

Muscle

Innervation

Flexion
  • Biceps femoris
  • Semitendinosus
  • Semimembranosus

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

Extension
  • Quadriceps femoris (Option A)

Femoral nerve

Medial rotation of flexed leg
  • Popliteus

Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Semimembranosus
  • Semitendinosus

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

Lateral rotation of flexed leg
  • Biceps femoris (Option C)

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

Locking
  • Vastus medialis (Option D)

Femoral nerve

Unlocking
  • Popliteus (Option B)

Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Locking

Unlocking

Medial rotation of the femur on the tibia during the terminal phase of extension.

Lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the initial phase of the flexion

It is brought about by the quadriceps femoris

It is brought about by the popliteus muscle

Locked knee becomes rigid

A 30-year-old primigravida gave birth to a healthy baby boy of 4 kg. She sustained an injury to the perineum involving internal and external anal sphincters. Which degree of perineal tear is this?
questions.explanation:
Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option B)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree (Option C)

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about polysaccharide vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They are often combined with a toxoid component to enhance the immune response against toxins produced by bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple immunizing agents are included in the vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: Polysaccharide based vaccines are available against S.pneumoniae, H.influenza b

questions.correct_answer: D. Polysaccharide based vaccines are available against S.pneumoniae, H.influenza b
questions.explanation:
Vaccine and Mechanism

Examples

Advantage / Disadvantage

Toxoid

(Option A)

Exotoxins produced by live organisms are used

Diphtheria, Tetanus, Anthrax

Highly efficacious

Highly safe

Protein vaccine

Specific proteins or peptides from the pathogen

Influenza vaccine (hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase), Acellular pertussis vaccine.

Less immunogenic

Conjugate vaccine

Polysaccharide antigen chemically linked to a protein recognized by Tcells.

Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine - PCV (used in NIS), Meningococcal.

Adv: More effective in children < 2 years (Option C)

D/A: Serotype specific

Recombinant Vaccine

Prepared by DNA technology.

Antigens are expressed on E. coli, yeast, and mammalian cells.

Hepatitis B, HPV, Cholera toxin B, Lyme disease

Adv: Safe

D/A: Less immunogenic and need an adjuvant to enhance efficiency

Combination Vaccine

(Option B)

More than one immunizing agent

MMR, DPT, Pentavalent

Overall reduction in adverse effects due to combination

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painful, irreducible groin hernia, severe colicky pain, bilious vomiting, and absence of faeces or flatus for 24 hours. The hernia is tense and extremely tender, with reddish-blue skin discolouration and no cough impulse. What is the immediate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer IV antibiotics and fluids and proceed with surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate surgical repair with synthetic mesh

options.label: C
options.text: Apply cold compresses to the hernia to reduce swelling

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer IV antibiotics and fluids and proceed with surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old tall, thin male presents with a dull, aching pain in his left groin and scrotum, describing a "bag of worms" sensation on palpation. He was suggested to undergo Palomo's Operation. Which of the following describes the procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein

questions.correct_answer: A. Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein
questions.explanation:
Common Occurrence
  • More common in tall, thin young men
  • More frequent on the left side, but can be bilateral

Causes
  • Idiopathic
  • Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein
  • Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein
  • Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein

Effects
  • Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility

Symptoms
  • Swelling at the root of the scrotum
  • Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum
  • "Bag of worms" feeling
  • Impulse on coughing
  • Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma)

Investigations
  • Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin
  • Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumors
  • Semen analysis

Treatment Options
  • Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein
  • Ligation of veins
  • Excision of veins

questions.text: A 40 y/o man presents with muscle weakness, bone pain, and polyuria. Lab tests show a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and glycosuria despite normal blood glucose levels. His urine pH is less than 5.5. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
RTA

Features

Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 2)
  • Caused by a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
  • Associated with generalized proximal tubular dysfunction.
  • Symptoms include low plasma bicarbonate, glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and hypokalemia
  • The urine pH may be acidic when plasma bicarbonate is low.

Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 1)
  • Results from an inability to acidify the urine in the distal tubule.
  • Characterized by persistently high urine pH (>5.5), hypokalemia, and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Often associated with nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis. (Option A)

Hyperkalemic Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 4)
  • Characterized by hyperkalemia and a mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Common in conditions such as diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. (Option C)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is scheduled for elective surgery requiring general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist decides to use thiopental sodium as an induction agent. Which of the following statements is true about thiopental sodium?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a long duration of action due to extensive renal metabolism.

options.label: B
options.text: Its rapid onset is primarily due to its high potency and redistribution.

options.label: C
options.text: It appears as a white milky liquid.

options.label: D
options.text: Its elimination half-life is approximately 1 hour.

questions.correct_answer: B. Its rapid onset is primarily due to its high potency and redistribution.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus is currently managed on metformin and gliclazide. However, his diabetes is not well-controlled, and he requires insulin therapy. He has a busy work schedule and prefers a regimen that minimises the number of daily injections. Which of the following insulin regimens would be most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin glargine once daily in the evening and Lispro three times before major meals

options.label: B
options.text: A premixed combination of regular and NPH insulin twice daily

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin Aspart injected before each meal

options.label: D
options.text: CSII with regular insulin using an insulin pump

questions.correct_answer: B. A premixed combination of regular and NPH insulin twice daily
questions.explanation:
PROPERTY

INTERMEDIATE-ACTING INSULIN

Specific preparation

Insulin zinc suspension (Lente insulin), Neutral protamine Hagedorn (NPH) insulin, or isophane insulin

Appearance

Cloudy solution

Onset of action

1-2 hours

Peak effect

8-10 hours

Effective duration

12-20 hours (Lente), 12-20 hours (NPH)

Compatibility

Can be mixed with regular insulin

Disadvantages

The time course of absorption and intensity of action are relatively inconsistent

Major adverse effect

Hypoglycemia

Additional Information

Intermediate-acting insulin is formulated to prolong insulin absorption.

It is often combined with regular insulin in a split-mixed regimen, subcutaneously twice daily, before breakfast and dinner.

Lente - Insulin zinc suspension.

NPH insulin is formulated by adding protamine to insulin in a quantity just sufficient to complex all the insulin molecules at a neutral pH.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with painless hematuria and weight loss over the past six months. CECT reveals a 9 cm enhancing mass in the right kidney, with evidence of invasion into the renal vein. Histopathology shows cells with clear cytoplasm and a delicate network of vasculature. Which of the following is the most likely variant of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.correct_answer: C. Clear cell renal cell carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Classification and salient features of variants of RCC

RCC Variants

Salient features

Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (CCRCC (Option C)
  • Most common variant
  • Usually sporadic
  • May be associated with the loss of chromosome 3p and a mutated von Hippel–Lindau gene
  • Macroscopic appearance: solid, golden-yellow tumor with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.
  • Microscopy: cells have clear cytoplasm due to the presence of abundant lipids and glycogen, surrounded by a delicate network of vasculature.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option B)
  • Second most common variant
  • It can be further divided into Type 1 and Type 2
  • Type 1 has small basophilic cells and Type 2 is characterized by large eosinophilic cells.
  • Type 1 has a better prognosis than type 2.
  • Associated with mutations in the MET gene - chromosome 7, 17, or Y.

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (Option A)
  • Arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts.
  • Microscopy: Characterized by large polygonal cells with prominent cell membranes and pale cytoplasm.
  • Better prognosis compared to other types of RCC.

Collecting duct carcinoma (Option D)
  • Also known as Bellini duct carcinoma.
  • Rare and aggressive form of RCC that arises from the collecting ducts in the renal medulla, hence centrally located.
  • Poor prognosis

Renal medullary carcinoma
  • Rare and aggressive
  • Associated with sickle cell trait in children
  • Centrally located

RTA type 2

RTA type 4

High

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue and exertional chest discomfort. His medical history is significant for hypertension and a family history of coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure and mild obesity. Laboratory investigations show elevated LDL cholesterol levels. Based on his risk factors and lab results, he is prescribed statin therapy. questions.explanation:
Effect

Explanation

↓ LDL cholesterol

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet paper for 2 weeks. She describes the pain as excruciating and sharp, akin to "passing glass.” Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It mainly presents with anal itching & discharge

options.label: B
options.text: The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.

options.label: C
options.text: This condition is characterized by a thickened anal papilla and a skin tag.

options.label: D
options.text: The majority of cases occur in the anterior midline in women due to childbirth.

questions.correct_answer: B. The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Cause

Trauma to the anal canal lining. (Passage of hard stools, prolonged diarrhoea, childbirth).

Increased anal sphincter tone converts acute to chronic fissure,

  • Elevated muscle tension reduces blood flow to the anal canal.
  • Impaired healing leads to a cycle of repeated injury.

Pain

Excruciating, sharp pain during defecation (described as "passing glass").

May be less intense than acute but can still be painful.

Duration of Pain

The pain subsides after defecation but returns with the next bowel movement. (Option B)

Persistent pain may occur, with periods of discomfort.

Bleeding

Bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping.

May also experience blood but less prominently reported.

Physical Exam

Difficult without anaesthesia due to intense pain.

An exam may be possible, with signs of irritation from the skin tag.

Additional Symptoms

Notable pain prevents physical examination; anal spasms may be present.

Presents with anal itching, discharge, or intersphincteric fistula. (Option A ruled out)

Identifying Features

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal.

Thickened anal papilla and skin tag present; fissure between these structures. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old student with a past history of suicide is brought to the emergency by his roommate, who found him unresponsive with an empty bottle of unknown pills. DMARD’s

2.

Golimumab

Anti-TNF𝛼

Inhibits IL1, IL6 TNF-Alpha in lymphocytes, reducing T cell activation.

7.

Sarilumab

Anti-IL-6

8.

Anti-CD-20

9.

Anakinra

Anti-IL-1

10.

Recombinant CTLA4, inhibits CD80/86

11.

12.

13.

Cleaved to 6-mercaptopurine (6MP) and inhibit purine synthesis

A 45-year-old male tourist from rural Egypt presents with recurrent hematuria and lower abdominal pain. A pelvic radiograph shows a circular calcification resembling a fetal head in the pelvis with associated faint calcification of the distal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Calcified bladder tumor; schedule CT urography

questions.correct_answer: B. Chronic schistosomiasis; obtain urine microscopy for ova
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Endemic regions

Africa, Middle-East (especially Egypt)

Clinical presentation

Recurrent hematuria, lower abdominal pain

Pathognomonic radiographic sign

questions.text: Carlos, a 40-year-old father and avid hiker, arrives at the emergency department after being bitten by a stray dog on his forearm while out on a rural trail. The bite is deep enough that it has broken the skin, causing some bleeding. Carlos mentions he's never received a rabies vaccination before and is anxious about the possibility of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in managing Carlos’s injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Clean the wound and reassure Carlos that no further treatment is necessary.

options.label: B
options.text: Clean the wound and administer a series of rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, without giving Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG).

options.label: C
options.text: Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.

options.label: D
options.text: Give Carlos a single dose of rabies vaccine and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) for rapid immunity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.
questions.explanation:
Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I

  • Touching or feeding animals

  • Licking of intact skin

  • Ensure proper hygiene

  • No treatment required

Category II

  • Nibbling on uncovered skin

  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

    • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III

  • Bites or scratches with bleeding

  • Licks on broken skin

  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.

  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

 

  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):

    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

  • Required for unvaccinated individuals

  • Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a known diagnosis of metastatic mesothelioma presents with worsening dyspnea and right-sided chest pain that is constant. Chest imaging is given below. What clinical finding is most likely to be present?

options.label: B
options.text: Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion

options.label: D
options.text: Bronchial breath sounds over the effusion

questions.correct_answer: B. Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion
questions.explanation:
Clinical findings of Pleural effusion

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, and systemic signs depending on the underlying cause.
  • Pleurisy, marked by sharp, localized pain during breathing or coughing, occurs with active pleural inflammation but typically subsides once the effusion forms.
  • Constant pain, however, is often associated with malignant conditions like mesothelioma.

Physical Examination
  • Dullness on percussion. (Option A ruled out)
  • Decreased breath sounds. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diminished tactile and vocal fremitus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Egophony is most pronounced at the upper part of the effusion. (Option B)
  • Pleural Rubs can be heard during active pleurisy and may be confused with coarse crackles.

History and Diagnostic Focus
  • Comprehensive history to explore potential causes of pulmonary and systemic effusions.
  • Assess for comorbidities, medications, infectious disease indicators, and malignancy risk factors.
  • Congestive Heart Failure: Suspected with jugular venous distension, S3 heart sound, and pedal oedema.
  • Liver Cirrhosis: Considered with signs such as ascites and caput medusae.
  • Primary TB: Cachexia, cough, hemoptysis, extreme breathlessness, night sweats, evening rise in temperature.

  • Pre-contrast preliminary.

Contraindications
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Active uterine bleeding.
  • Allergic to iodine.
  • Pregnancy.

Doxycycline can be given
  • If dilated tubes are identified (indicating previous pelvic infection).
  • As prophylaxis to prevent infections post-HSG.

Complications
  • Pelvic discomfort.
  • Uterine perforation.
  • Vasovagal reactions.
  • Dye allergy.
  • Intravascular dissemination of the dye.

questions.explanation:
Description and Pathophysiology
  • Nuclear cataract/ sclerosis: The etiology is nuclear sclerosis.
  • Results from the gradual loss of lens elasticity and transparency due to dehydration, and increase in water-insoluble proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Glare
  • Diplopia
  • Colored Halos
  • Blurred Vision/ Gradual Vision Loss
  • Black spots in front of eyes.
  • Deterioration of vision:
    • In some patients with nuclear sclerosis, near vision improves due to progressive index myopia.
    • Such patients may have improvement in their near-vision glasses.
    • This improvement in near vision is referred to as 'second sight.’

Grading
  • Nuclear Opacity (NO): Ranges from 1 (slight opacification) to 5 (severe opacity).
  • Nuclear Color (NC): Ranges from 1 (amber) to 5 (black).
  • Cataracta brunescens (amber-brown), Cataracta rubra (red), Cataracta nigra (black)

Management
  • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
  • Cataract surgeries:
    • ICCE (not preferred now)
    • ECCE
    •  SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
    •  Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
  • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents to the clinic with noticeable cognitive decline. She is diagnosed with Dementia with Lewy Bodies. Which of the following is not a core feature of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Core Features

Supporting Features
  • Fluctuating levels of attention and alertness (Option A ruled out)
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations (Option B ruled out)
  • Parkinsonian features (e.g., cogwheeling, bradykinesia, resting tremor) (Option D ruled out)
  • REM Sleep behavior disorder
  • Repeated falls
  • Syncope
  • Sensitivity to neuroleptics
  • Systematized delusions (Option C)
  • Hallucinations in other modalities (e.g., auditory, tactile)

Feature

Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)

Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Onset of Symptoms

Cognitive and psychiatric symptoms appear early; motor symptoms develop later.

Primarily motor symptoms appear first (e.g., bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors).

Visual Hallucinations

Common and can occur early.

Less common initially; may occur later, often due to treatment.

Fluctuations in Attention

Fluctuations in alertness and attention are characteristic.

Fluctuations are primarily related to medication cycles.

Response to Medications

Poor response to dopaminergic medications; risk of worsening psychiatric symptoms.

Generally improves with dopaminergic medications (e.g., levodopa).

Sleep Disturbances

REM sleep behavior disorder is common and can precede cognitive symptoms.

REM sleep behavior disorder may occur but is primarily linked to motor symptoms.

Progression

Rapid progression of cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Gradual progression of motor symptoms, with cognitive decline developing later.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of burning epigastric pain that occurs 1-2 hours after meals and is temporarily relieved by food. He also complains of vomiting. On examination, his heart rate is 115 beats per minute, and his temperature is 98.6°F. Mild epigastric tenderness is noted, and laboratory tests show mild anemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gastric Ulcer (GU)

Duodenal Ulcer (DU)

Common risk factors for both GU and DU: H. pylori, indiscriminate use of NSAIDS due to comorbidities in the patients like osteoarthritis or requiring total knee replacement, etc.
  • > 6th-decade
  • Premalignant condition.
  • MC site: Lesser curvature of stomach.
  • Basal/Nocturnal acid production: ↑
  • MC site: First part of duodenum or duodenal cap, usually within 3 cm of the pylorus.
  • Size of Ulcer: <1 cm.

Pain Pattern: Pain is precipitated by food.

Pain Pattern: Pain occurs 90 min to 3 h after a meal and is relieved by food or antacids.

Common Features:

  1. Epigastric pain (gnawing or burning sensation)
  2. Epigastric tenderness
  3. Tachycardia and Orthostasis caused by:
  • Vomiting, may be due to pylorospasm or local edema
  • GI bleeding
  1. Rigidity in the anterior abdominal wall is suggestive of perforation
  2. Succussion splash: Gastric outlet obstruction (due to pyloric stenosis, pylorospasm, or local edema due to ulcer in the peripyloric area or fibrosis extending to the duodenum).

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the OPD with severe pain, redness, and swelling in his right knee. Examination reveals tender swelling and redness at the base of the right 1st toe. Serum urate levels are normal, but arthrocentesis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarised light. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this acute attack?
questions.explanation:
Management of acute gout attack

Colchicine

(Option B)
  • Microtubule inhibitor, which prevents microtubule assembly in neutrophils, thus reducing inflammation.
  • Colchicine disrupts the function of the cytoskeleton by inhibiting the polymerization of beta-tubulin into microtubules.
  • This prevents the formation and function of microtubules, which are essential for various cellular processes.
  • By disrupting microtubule formation, colchicine inhibits the activation, degranulation, and migration of neutrophils, which are key players in the inflammatory response. This reduces the inflammatory cascade associated with conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine does not prevent phagocytosis of uric acid crystals, but it inhibits the release of an inflammatory glycoprotein from phagocytes. This contributes to its anti-inflammatory action in conditions like gout.
  • Colchicine blocks metaphase in dividing cells by disrupting mitotic spindle formation.
  • DOC for acute attacks of gout.
  • Dose: 0.6 mg TID - introduced after 2-3 days when swelling reduces.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

NSAIDs
  • It is effective when used early in an attack of gout.
  • Indomethacin 25-50 mg TID / Naproxen 500 mg BID / Ibuprofen 800 mg TID
  • Avoided in elderly patients and those with renal impairment

Glucocorticoids

(Option C)
  • It can be used as an intramuscular injection for multi-articular involvement or intra-articular injection for mono-articular involvement, or orally.
  • Safe to use in elderly patients and those with renal impairment.

Other treatments

  • Ice therapy: Reduces swelling and inflammation
  • Canakinumab (IL-1 β inhibitor) (Option A)
  • Anakinra: Reserved for resistant cases

Urate lowering agents

  • Drugs: Allopurinol, Febuoxostat, Probenecid and Pegloticase
  • Contraindicated in acute attacks.
  • Rapidly reduces serum urate level, which causes the dissolution of organised monosodium urate crystals.
  • Causes an inflammatory reaction towards the shed crystals.

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm)

Hymenolepis nana, or dwarf tapeworm, is a parasitic cestode primarily infecting humans and rodents, commonly causing infection in children.

It can complete its life cycle in a single host without requiring an intermediate host.

Morphology
  • Adult Worm: Measures 15–40 mm in length; features a scolex with four suckers and a retractable rostellum with hooks for attachment to the intestinal wall.
  • Proglottids: Segmented body, with each segment containing both male and female reproductive organs.

Life Cycle
  • Infective Stage: Eggs are excreted in feces and can survive in the environment.
  • Autoinfection: Ingested eggs hatch in the intestine, allowing direct development into adults, leading to reinfection.
  • Ingestion: Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated food or water. Rodents can also act as hosts.
  • Larval Development: Oncospheres hatch in the intestine, penetrate intestinal villi, and develop into cysticercoids.
  • Maturation: Cysticercoids mature into adults in about 20–30 days, attaching to the intestinal wall and producing eggs.

Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic in many cases.
  • Symptomatic individuals may experience:
    • Abdominal pain and cramps
    • Diarrhea or loose stools
    • Loss of appetite and weight loss
    • Irritability (especially in children)
    • Nausea and vomiting (less common)

Investigations
  • Stool Examination: Microscopic detection of eggs using methods like Kato-Katz or concentration techniques.
  • PCR: Used for specific identification of H. nana DNA in stool samples.

Management

Antiparasitic Medication:

  • Praziquantel: First-line treatment, typically a single oral dose of 25 mg/kg.
  • Alternative: Nitazoxanide.

Features

Taenia Species

Diphyllobothrium latum

Hymenolepis nana

Hymenolepis diminuta

Egg Appearance

Brownish/yellow-brown, thick-shelled

Yellow-brown, operculated

Similar to H. nana, slightly larger

50-76 µm

30-45 µm

40-70 µm

Shape

Ellipsoidal

Oval to Spherical

Oval to Spherical

Shell Characteristics

Striated (thick)

Operculum at one end, thin shell

Smooth, no striations

Smooth, no striations

Bile Staining

Negative

Positive

Negative

Negative

Other Features

Contains hooks in the larval stage (cysticercus); no hooks in T. saginata

Terminal knob at the opposite end

Contains polar filaments

Polar filaments, typically absent

Embryo Development

Cysticercus larva can develop within the host

Proglottids shed in water, release eggs

Can develop into an adult in a single host.

questions.text: Match the following images of forceps with their names. 1. a. Simpson forceps 2. b. Piper forceps 3. c. Wrigley's forceps 4.​​​​​​​ d. Kielland forceps
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, including difficulty in starting urination, weak urinary stream, and frequent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, he has a history of trauma to the pelvic region. A retrograde urethrogram (RGU) reveals a stricture in the anterior urethra measuring more than 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

questions.correct_answer: C. Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa
questions.explanation:
Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra, causing partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhea and chlamydia causing urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding.

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).


Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence. (Option A)

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).(Option B)

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures (Option C).

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast

options.label: D
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.correct_answer: D. Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years
questions.explanation:
Overview
  • Histologic marker of increased breast cancer risk, not true cancer.
  • It involves an abnormal proliferation of cells within the lobules of the breast without invasion through the basement membrane.
  • Subsequent invasive cancers are predominantly ductal, not lobular
Characteristics
  • Occurs mainly in younger, premenopausal women
  • Typically an incidental finding during biopsy
  • No palpable masses or suspicious mammographic microcalcifications
  • Bilateral
Risk
  • 21.4% chance of developing carcinoma over 35 years
  • 7:1 risk ratio for invasive breast cancer
  • 50% of subsequent carcinomas in contralateral breast
Management
  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

Clinical Significance
  • Lifelong breast cancer risk affecting both breasts equally 
  • Risk slightly less than 1% per year

questions.text: A 40 year old woman presents with complaints of persistent nausea, vomiting, and frequent urination over the past few weeks. She has a history of osteomalacia and has been taking supplements for several months without proper medical supervision. Her blood tests reveal elevated serum calcium levels. questions.explanation:
Aspect

Vitamin D Deficiency

Vitamin D Toxicity

Causes

Inadequate dietary intake, insufficient sun exposure, malabsorption syndromes, and certain medical conditions affecting metabolism.

Excessive supplementation.

Dietary intake and sun exposure rarely cause toxicity.

Symptoms

Bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures; in children, it leads to rickets; in adults, it leads to osteomalacia or osteoporosis.

Nausea, vomiting, weakness, frequent urination, and hypercalcemia; can lead to kidney stones and kidney damage.

Serum Levels

Defined as 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) < 30 ng/mL, indicating insufficient levels.

Occurs when 25(OH)D > 150 ng/mL, leading to adverse health effects.

Treatment

Managed with dietary supplementation via food or medications and increased sun exposure.

Requires discontinuation of vitamin D intake, intravenous fluids, and medications, such as corticosteroids or bisphosphonates.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents for routine follow-up. According to the 2023 GOLD classification, which group does this patient belong to?

Group

Treatment

Goals

Short-acting bronchodilators (e.g., albuterol) as needed.

Symptom control and improved quality of life.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is primarily classified as a water-washed disease?
questions.explanation:
Type of Disease Definition/Transmission Examples
Water Borne Caused by ingestion of pathogens in contaminated water. Cholera, Typhoid, Diarrhea, Hepatitis A and E, GI infections, Polio.
Water Washed Due to lack of clean water for washing, leading to poor hygiene and sanitation. Infective trachoma, Scabies, Conjunctivitis, Bacillary Amoebic dysentery, Worm infestations.
Water Based Due to the intermediate host in water - Contact with or ingestion of water containing the organisms. Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm disease), Schistosomiasis
Water related/Breeding Diseases that are transmitted by vectors which breed in or near water such as mosquitoes. Malaria, Dengue fever, Japanese Encephalitis, Chikungunya.

questions.text: During a food festival in a small town, 200 people attended a barbecue event. Within 48 hours, 60 attendees developed symptoms of food poisoning. A 45 y/o woman with a long-standing history of non-allergic rhinitis presents with persistent nasal obstruction and rhinorrhoea that has not responded to antihistamines and nasal steroid sprays. Which of the following would be the next best step in managing her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the dose of topical steroid sprays

options.label: B
options.text: Start systemic steroids for a short period and add ipratropium bromide nasal spray

questions.correct_answer: B. Start systemic steroids for a short period and add ipratropium bromide nasal spray
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Details

Lifestyle Modifications
  • Avoid triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, air blasts, and dust.
  • Practical changes to minimise symptom triggers

Pharmacological Management
  • Antihistamines and Decongestants: Alleviate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and rhinorrhoea.
  • Topical Steroid Sprays: Control Symptoms. Eg. Beclomethasone dipropionate, budesonide, fluticasone
  • Systemic Steroids: Used for severe cases for a short time
  • Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray: Effective for Excessive Rhinorrhoea.

Psychological Support

Address emotional factors; consider counselling and tranquillisers.

Surgical Procedure

Details

Examples/Notes

Turbinate Reduction

Reduces nasal obstruction by shrinking turbinate size; also corrects other obstructions.

Submucosal diathermy, resection, cryosurgery, turbinectomy, cauterisation, laser, coblation, radiofrequency.

Vidian Neurectomy

Considered for persistent excessive rhinorrhoea despite medical therapy.

It involves sectioning parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the nose.

Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

High stationery

High

High

Population is stable

Early expanding

  • Aka Demographic trap

Late expanding

Declining

questions.text: A 50 year old female patient is undergoing a minor surgical procedure on her left forearm using intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) for pain control. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops seizures and exhibits signs of cardiovascular instability. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Give an additional bolus of lidocaine

questions.explanation:
Indications
  • Suitable for minor surgical procedures on the upper or lower extremities (hand surgeries, forearm procedures, and foot surgeries).
  • Used when general anesthesia is not necessary and for patients with contraindications to other forms of anesthesia.

Anesthetic Agents
  • Commonly used local anesthetics include lidocaine (most frequent) and prilocaine.

Procedure Steps
  • Tourniquet Application: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal part of the extremity to prevent blood flow and keep the local anesthetic localized.
  • Venous Access: Establish intravenous access in the selected limb.
  • Administration of Anesthetic agent: Inject the local anesthetic into the IV line, typically in a volume of 40-50 mL.

Tourniquet Management

  • The tourniquet should be inflated to a pressure that is approximately 50 mmHg above systolic blood pressure.
  • It is typically safe to keep the tourniquet inflated for 30-60 minutes; prolonged inflation can increase the risk of complications.

Advantages
  • Provides effective analgesia with minimal systemic absorption.
  • Allows for a bloodless surgical field.
  • Quick onset of action and ease of administration.

Disadvantages and Complications
  • Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) Can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation.
  • Tourniquet Pain
  • Nerve Damage

Contraindications
  • Infection at the injection site or over the tourniquet.
  • Severe peripheral vascular disease.
  • Patient refusal or inability to cooperate.

Lipid Emulsion Therapy
  • Used as a treatment for Local anesthesia systemic toxicity, acts by sequestering the local anesthetic from circulation and mitigating toxic effects.
  • Administer a 20% lipid emulsion intravenously if toxicity occurs.

questions.text: All of the following changes are true during pregnancy except:
questions.explanation:
Change in Pregnancy

Reason

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

Unchanged

Does not increase during pregnancy; it typically decreases slightly due to decreased systemic vascular resistance despite elevated cardiac output. (Option D)

Systolic Blood Pressure

Decrease

Systemic vascular resistance decreases due to the relaxing effects of progesterone, nitric oxide, prostaglandins, and ANP, leading to lower blood pressure. (Option A)

Stroke Volume

Increase

Blood volume increases during pregnancy, increasing preload and subsequently increasing stroke volume (amount of blood pumped per heart contraction). (Option B)

Pulse Rate

Increase

Heart rate increases by about 15 beats per minute during pregnancy to support the increased cardiac output necessary for the growing fetus. (Option C)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient with newly diagnosed pulmonary TB begins treatment with ATT. After several weeks of therapy, he complains of difficulty distinguishing colors and experiencing blurred vision. On examination, he exhibits decreased visual acuity and bilateral central scotomas. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green color blindness (Yellow vision- Digoxin; Blue vision- Sildenafil)
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

questions.text: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?

A 28-year-old male with schizophrenia, who has been stable on antipsychotics for years, was recently switched to a higher dose of a first-generation antipsychotic. He then becomes increasingly agitated, develops a high fever, and exhibits severe muscle stiffness, appearing less responsive and confused. The involved receptors and the drug of choice for managing this condition are:
questions.explanation:
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

Description

A rare, potentially fatal consequence of neuroleptic administration.

Mechanism

D2 receptor blocking at:

  • Striatum (muscle rigidity)
  • Hypothalamus (hyperthermia)
  • Spinal nerves (autonomic disturbances)
 

Clinical manifestations

Motor and behavioural

Autonomic symptoms
  • Muscular rigidity (most common)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia,
  • Mutism
  • Obtundation
  • Agitation
  • Fever (most common)
  • Diaphoresis
  • Raised pulse and blood pressure
  • Sweating
  • Altered consciousness

Associated conditions

Renal failure and myoglobinuria

Laboratory findings
  • Raised levels of creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) (most common)
  • Leukocytosis (raised WBC)
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised plasma myoglobin

Management

  • Stop the drug (causing symptoms)
  • Supportive care (maintain hydration and other vitals)
  • Skeletal muscle relaxants: Dantrolene sodium (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Amantadine
  • Second-generation antipsychotics (for restarting the treatment for Schizophrenia).

  • Imperforate hymen (Cryptomenorrhea) 
  • Vaginal agenesis
  • Transverse vaginal septum 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction
  • Kallmann’s syndrome
  • Craniopharyngioma

Abnormal chromosomal pattern
  • Turner’s syndrome (most common cause)
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
