questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 26 weeks of gestation visits the antenatal clinic for her routine check-up. Her haemoglobin (Hb) level is found to be 8.5 g/dl. It was 10 g/dl at her booking visit. She has been compliant with her IFA supplementation. What should be the next step in managing this patient’s anaemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue with oral Iron and Folic Acid tablets and recheck Hb after one month.

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose).

options.label: C
options.text: Refer to the higher center for further investigation and management.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the dose of oral Iron and Folic Acid tablets and recheck Hb after two weeks.

questions.correct_answer: C. Refer to the higher center for further investigation and management.
questions.explanation:
Anaemia management protocol for pregnant women

Target Group

Pregnant women registered for antenatal care

Screening and Periodicity

By health service provider at every ANC checkup

Degree

Of anaemia

First Level of Treatment

Follow-up

If No Improvement

Mild anaemia (Hb 10–10.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance.
  • Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose
  • Refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) if Hb <1 g/dl increase after one month of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Moderate anaemia (Hb 7–9.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases.
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance. Monthly Hb estimation. Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose.
  • Refer to FRU/DH if Hb <1 g/dl increase after two months of treatment Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Severe anaemia (Hb 5.0–6.9 g/dl)
  • Managed by medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH.
  • Treatment with IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxymaltose.
  • Immediate hospitalization in the third trimester is recommended at higher facility.
  • Monthly or as prescribed by the medical officer
  • Follow treatment protocol as prescribed by the medical officer

questions.text: “The risk of contracting a disease increases if profit is valued more than health”. This statement represents which of the following theories in sociology?

Marxist theory
  • Putting profit as a priority instead of health
  • Eg: Alcohol and tobacco consumption is not completely banned as it leads to loss of revenue

Parsonian theory
  • Social factors like poverty, migration and industrialisation playing a role in disease etiology

Feminist theory
  • Females are enforced by men to do particular roles

Foucauldian theory
  • By segregating the population into groups, they can be controlled easily

Mckeown’s theory of TB
  • Changes in socio-environmental conditions lead to a reduction in TB

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the Delphi technique?

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: A statistical analysis method used to interpret large datasets through the use of complex algorithms.

questions.correct_answer: C. A structured communication technique used in health research that relies on a panel of experts answering questionnaires in multiple rounds to achieve consensus.

questions.text: An elderly patient with a history of an intracapsular neck of femur fracture presents with hip pain radiating to the groin and thigh, worsening with activity but improving with rest. Examination reveals restricted range of motion and tenderness in the hip. Which of the following arteries is not typically involved in the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to such a presentation?
questions.explanation:
Blood Supply Source

Description

Retinacular Vessels
  • Major supply, derived from the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries (branches of the deep femoral artery).
  • Forms an extensive network along the femoral neck.

Intraosseous Cervical Vessels
  • Secondary source, providing additional vascular support through small penetrating vessels along the femoral neck.

Artery of Ligamentum Teres
  • Tertiary source, also called the foveolar artery.
  • Supplies the femoral head via the ligamentum teres.
  • Important in younger patients or in cases of trauma.

Obturator Artery
  • Provides minor support through its acetabular branch.
  • Primarily supplies the medial thigh muscles but contributes to anastomoses around the hip joint.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain, high fever, and an elevated heart rate. options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with hypertension presents with profuse nasal bleeding from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, unresponsive to pinching and anterior packing. Bleeding that flows backwards into the throat

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with signs of early virilization and ambiguous genitalia. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ACTH and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Enzyme Deficiency

Description

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase deficiency

Fatal in utero, prevents placental progesterone synthesis.

Death before birth.

Steroidogenic acute regulatory (StAR) protein deficiency

Known as congenital lipoid adrenal hyperplasia. Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency

Increases DHEA secretion (weak androgen).

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males. (Option C)

17α-Hydroxylase deficiency

Caused by mutated CYP17 gene. Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia due to high 11-deoxycorticosterone. (Option D- not early virilization)

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

Increased 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone secretion.

Virilization, hypertension due to salt and water retention. (Option A)

Enzyme Deficiency

Impact

Symptoms/Consequences

Cholesterol desmolase

Prevents progesterone synthesis.

Fatal in utero.

StAR protein

Prevents cholesterol movement into mitochondria.

Low steroid production, female genitalia regardless of genetic sex.

3β-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase

Increases DHEA.

Masculinization in females, hypospadias in males.

17α-Hydroxylase

Prevents sex hormone production.

Female external genitalia, hypertension, hypokalemia.

11β-Hydroxylase

Increases 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone.

Virilization, hypertension.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent eye discomfort, redness, and watering. On examination, the left eye is diffusely tender, sclera appears uniformly reddened and swollen without localized thinning areas. There are no systemic signs of vasculitis or autoimmune disease on further investigation. Which type of anterior scleritis is most consistent with this presentation?

A 4-year-old boy has been brought to the emergency department with severe vomiting for the past 2 days. He appears dehydrated and lethargic. Laboratory studies reveal: pH: 7.52 pCO2: 38 mmHg HCO3-: 32 mEq/L Na+: 138 mEq/L Cl-: 90 mEq/L Urinary Chloride: 10 mEq/L Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial treatment for this patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.explanation:
Acid-Base Disorder

Primary Cause

Initial Treatment

Additional Considerations

Metabolic Acidosis

Excess HCO3- loss or H+ retention
  • Treat underlying cause
  • Fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline)
  • Start sodium bicarbonate (Option A)
  • Sodium bicarbonate rarely used, only if pH < 7.1 or life-threatening
  • Address electrolyte imbalances after initial resuscitation

Respiratory Acidosis

CO2 retention due to respiratory compromise
  • Assisted ventilation (NIV/IMV)
  • Treat underlying cause

For every 10 mmHg increase in pCO2, there is 4 mEq/L rise in HCO3- (metabolic compensation)

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Responsive)
  • HCl loss (e.g., vomiting)
  • Urinary chloride < 15 mEq/L
  • Volume repletion with normal saline
  • Most common type
  • Responds to fluid and chloride replacement

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Resistant)
  • Various endocrine disorders
  • Urinary chloride > 20 mEq/L
  • Treat underlying cause
  • May require specific treatments based on etiology (e.g., spironolactone for Liddle syndrome)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Does not respond to volume repletion alone
  • Requires targeted therapy based on specific diagnosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

CO2 washout due to hyperventilation
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., fever, sepsis, asthma)
  • Adjust ventilator settings if over ventilated
  • Monitor for hypocalcemia (may cause tetany, seizures)
  • Metabolic compensation occurs over days

> 36 hours

Desquamation over 75% of body surface

> 1 week

Mouth is widely open

Throughout process

  • No gas formation

questions.text: Match the following research trials/programs with their respective objectives: i) MRFIT a. Surveillance and assessment of trends in cardiovascular events ii) Jai vigyan mission b. Decreasing serum cholesterol, diastolic BP, smoking cessation in lowering coronary heart disease mortality iii) MONICA c. Dietary approaches to stop HTN iv) MPOWER d. To control rheumatic heart disease v) DASH e. To control consumption of Tobacco
questions.correct_answer: C. i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e, v-c
questions.explanation:
Multiple risk factor intervention Trial (MRFIT)
  • It is a randomised, primary prevention trial
  • Its objective is to check whether decreasing high levels of serum cholesterol, DBP and smoking cessation would help in reducing coronary heart disease mortality.

MPOWER
  • Monitor tobacco use and prevention policies
  • Protect people from use of tobacco
  • Offer help for quitting tobacco use
  • Warn about the dangers with tobacco use
  • Enforce bans on tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship
  • Raise taxes on tobacco

MONICA
  • Monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease
  • Surveillance and assessment in trends of cardiovascular disease

Dietary approaches to stop hypertension

(DASH)
  • Consume a diet rich in vegetables, fruits and low fat dairy products with low content of saturated and total fats
  • Helps in decreasing around 8-14 mm hg of SBP

Jai Vigyan mission
  • Surveillance for finding out epidemiological determinants for Group A strep and sore throat.
  • Establishment of registry of RHD/RF all over the country
  • To promote vaccine development
  • To promote research and studies for investigations of RHD/RF

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy for the treatment of Graves' disease. Two days postoperatively, she presents with numbness and tingling around her mouth and in her fingers. She also complains of muscle cramps and mild weakness. Laboratory tests reveal decreased serum calcium levels. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms following the surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands
questions.explanation:
HYPOPARATHYROIDISM

Common Causes:

Thyroid Surgery

Most frequent cause.

is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply. (Option B)

Risk Factors:

  • Bilateral neck exploration,
  • Extensive central neck dissection,
  • Revision surgery,
  • Thyroidectomy for Graves' disease,
  • Pediatric patients.

Autoimmune Disorders

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

Genetic Conditions

DiGeorge syndrome, autosomal dominant hypocalcemia.

Radiation Therapy

Radiation to the neck area can damage parathyroid glands.

Medications

Lithium, and some chemotherapeutic agents (Pembrolizumab).

Prevention:

  • Surgical Precautions:
  • Careful dissection and preservation of parathyroid glands.
  • Examine surgical specimens for removed parathyroid tissue.
  • Autotransplant confirmed parathyroid tissue into the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • Calcium and Vit D Supplementation:
    • Administer calcium (with/without calcitriol) proactively for total thyroidectomy patients.
    • Measure intraoperative PTH or intact PTH levels four hours postoperatively to guide supplementation.

Management:

  • Temporary Hypoparathyroidism: Resolves within 6 months.
  • Permanent Hypoparathyroidism: Requires ongoing calcium and/or Vit D replacement.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent bacterial infections, delayed wound healing, and poor pus formation. questions.correct_answer: A. Impaired leukocyte rolling and weak adhesion
questions.explanation:
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Defective leukocyte rolling and weak adhesion because of mutations in fucosyl transferase required for the synthesis of sialylated oligosaccharide (receptor for selectins)

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 3

LAD-III is caused by mutations in the FERMT3 gene, which encodes kindlin-3, a cytoskeletal protein. These mutations disrupt the signalling of integrins on platelets and leukocytes, which impairs cellular adhesion

questions.text: A forensic investigator is analyzing a crime scene for potential blood stains. They decide to use a presumptive test that can detect trace amounts of blood but may also give false positives with other substances like bleach or rust. Chemiluminescent reaction occurs when luminol reacts with hemoglobin under alkaline conditions, producing a blue glow.

Similar to Luminol

Same as Luminol

Kastle Meyer

Presumptive

1:16,384 dilution

High

Minimal

Hemastix

Presumptive

1:64 dilution

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, fixed, non-tender, lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 cm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A)

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B)

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C)

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D)

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following breast lesions are correctly paired with their histopathological characteristics? 1. Fibrocystic changes 2. Duct ectasia 3. Phyllodes tumor 4. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Fibrocystic changes

Cysts: Fluid-filled sacs within the breast tissue, often surrounded by fibrous tissue.

Fibrosis: Thickening and scarring of breast tissue, which may result in palpable lumps or areas of increased density on imaging studies.

Apocrine Metaplasia: Transformation of ductal epithelial cells into apocrine-like cells, characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and apical snouts.

Duct ectasia

A lot of foamy macrophages, periductal lymphocytic infiltrates can be observed.

Phyllodes tumor

Increased stromal cellularity and overgrowth, giving rise to the typical leaf-like architecture.

Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS)

Types of DCIS:

  • Micropapillary tumors: Additional epithelial cells within the lumen.
  • Cribriform tumors: Ducts filled with cells that form multiple lumena.
  • Solid tumors: Completely filled ducts.
  • Comedo tumors: Solid with a necrotic core

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC)

Shows more mucin both extracellular and intracellular with signet ring cells.

Fibroadenoma

Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.

  • Intracanalicular fibroadenoma - Ducts are compressed.

  • Pericanalicular fibroadenoma - Ducts are open.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening ascites, oliguria, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals tense ascites, mild jaundice, and peripheral edema. Laboratory investigations show: Serum creatinine: 2.3 mg/dL (baseline: 0.9 mg/dL) Serum sodium: 126 mEq/L Urine sodium: <10 mEq/L Albumin infusion is planned as part of his management. What is the recommended dosage of albumin infusion for this patient?
questions.explanation:
• Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Location of the lesion

Characteristic features

Optic nerve
  • Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated.
  • Near (accommodation) reflex is present.

Optic chiasma
  • Bitemporal hemianopia

Optic tract
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.

Optic radiations
  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky)
    • Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions)
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor)
    • Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions.

Visual cortex
  • Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents for a routine eye examination. His intraocular pressure (IOP) is consistently measured at 23 mm Hg on multiple occasions. He reports no visual symptoms, and his fundus examination shows no abnormalities. Visual field testing reveals no defects. Based on these findings, which of the following diagnoses is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
ASPECT

OCULAR HYPERTENSION

(Option B)

NORMAL TENSION GLAUCOMA

(Option A)

Characteristic Features
  • IOP consistently above 21 mm Hg (No Damage)
  • No Fundus findings
  • No visual field defects
  • IOP is normal.
  • Fundus changes Present
  • Visual field defect present
  • The anterior chamber angle is open on gonioscopy, and there is no secondary cause for the changes.

Risk Factors
  • Consistent IOP >30 mm Hg.
  • Central corneal thickness <550 µm.
  • Vertical cup-to-disc ratio >0.7.
  • Increased age.
  • Increased pattern standard deviation (PSD) on Humphrey visual field test.
  • Disc hemorrhages (splinter hemorrhages near or over the disc).
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Migraine: Increased risk.
  • Nocturnal systemic hypotension: Low blood pressure during the night, or overtreated systemic hypertension.
  • Reduced blood flow velocity in the ophthalmic artery

Management
  • When these risk factors are present, treatment may be initiated similarly to open-angle glaucoma, but with a less aggressive approach.

Medical Treatment:

  • Target the IOP levels to be around 12-14 mm Hg.
  • Prostaglandin analogues (e.g., latanoprost) are preferred for their effective ocular hypotensive effect.
  • Beta blockers and adrenergic drugs should be avoided due to potential adverse effects on optic nerve perfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match of brainstem components with the respective cranial nerve nuclei that originate from them? Column A Column B a. Midbrain 1. Trigeminal nerve b. Pons 2. Oculomotor nerve c. Medulla oblongata 3. Glossopharyngeal nerve d. Pontomedullary junction 4. Facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Components of brainstem

Cranial nerves nuclei

Midbrain

Oculomotor (III) and trochlear (IV)

Pons

Trigeminal (V)

Medulla oblongata

Glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), cranial accessory (XIcr) and hypoglossal (XII)

Pontomedullary junction

Abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of premature birth presents with spasticity predominantly in the lower limbs. Which of the following pathology is associated with this type of presentation?
questions.explanation:
Type

Neuropathology

Major Causes

Spastic Diplegia

  • Periventricular leukomalacia (Option B)
  • Periventricular cysts/scars
  • Enlarged ventricles
  • Premature birth
  • Ischemia
  • Infection
  • Endocrine/metabolic issues (e.g., thyroid)

Spastic Quadriplegia

  • Periventricular leukomalacia
  • Multicystic encephalomalacia
  • Ischemia
  • Infection
  • Endocrine/metabolic issues
  • Genetic/developmental problems

Hemiplegia)

  • In utero/neonatal stroke
  • Focal infarct (Option C)
  • Cortical/subcortical damage
  • Thrombophilic causes
  • Infection
  • Genetic/developmental issues

Extrapyramidal (Athetoid, Dyskinetic)

  • Kernicterus (scars in globus pallidus/hippocampus)
  • Mitochondrial scarring
  • Asphyxia

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has been complaining of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and swelling in his ankles and legs over the past few months. On physical examination, you notice hepatomegaly and proteinuria. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum creatinine levels and microscopic hematuria. Which of the following types of amyloid is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?

A 3-year-old child presents with acute onset of barking cough, hoarseness, and mild respiratory distress that worsens at night. Physical examination reveals inspiratory stridor but normal lung fields. The child attends preschool where several other children have similar symptoms. The illness started with mild upper respiratory symptoms 2 days ago. No other significant clinical findings are seen. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Parainfluenza Virus

Clinical Features
  • Croup (Types 1 and 2)
  • Lower respiratory disease (Type 3)
  • Mild respiratory illness (Type 4)
  • Adults: mild URI, hoarseness
  • Rarely causes parotitis

Epidemiology
  • Type 3: Common in the first year of life
  • Types 1 & 2: Preschool children
  • First infections more serious
  • 50% of infants become seropositive by 12 months

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Specimen: Throat/nasal swabs
  • Virus isolation: Monkey kidney cells
  • Serology: Paired sera samples
  • PCR: Most rapid and sensitive

Transmission
  • Air/respiratory droplets
  • Through fingers
  • Nosocomial spread uncommon
  • No vaccine available

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with developmental delay, ataxic gait, and frequent inappropriate laughter. Genetic testing reveals a deletion in the 15q11-q13 region of the maternal chromosome. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.correct_answer: B. Disorder with paternal uniparental disomy
questions.explanation:
Feature

Angelman Syndrome

Prader-Willi Syndrome

Genetic Cause

Deletion or mutation of the maternal UBE3A gene on chromosome 15q11-q13.

Deletion or mutation of the paternal region on chromosome 15q11-q13, or maternal uniparental disomy.

Developmental Milestones

Severe developmental delay; speech is often minimal or absent.

Mild to moderate developmental delay; speech and motor skills are delayed.

Physical Features

Microcephaly, frequent smiling/laughter, ataxia, seizures.

Hypotonia, obesity, short stature, small hands and feet.

Behavioral Characteristics

Happy demeanor, hyperactivity, fascination with water.

Food-seeking behavior, temper tantrums, compulsive behaviors.

Intellectual Disability

Severe to profound intellectual disability.

Mild to moderate intellectual disability.

Seizures

Common and often severe.

Rare, typically not a prominent feature.

Growth Patterns

Normal or mildly affected growth; often underweight.

Hyperphagia leading to obesity if not managed.

Sleep Disturbances

Frequent, often severe sleep disturbances.

Common, often associated with excessive daytime sleepiness.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for inhibiting motor neuron activity at the level of the spinal cord to regulate muscle tone and reflexes?

A 52 year old chronic alcoholic presents to the ED with confusion, difficulty walking, and abnormal eye movements. He reports having consumed large amounts of alcohol daily for many years and has had poor dietary intake. On examination, he has nystagmus and an unsteady gait. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome (Cerebral Beriberi)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation. (Option B ruled out)

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Impaired intestinal absorption of thiamine due to alcohol. Increased thiamine utilization and inadequate dietary intake.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

 Symmetrical T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, periaqueductal gray matter, and around the third ventricle.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a painless, firm, mobile lump in her breast. On physical examination, the lump is approximately 1 cm in diameter, firm, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile. Ultrasound confirms a well-defined, solid, homogeneous mass with smooth margins and no signs of calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis and management plan?

options.label: B
options.text: Fibroadenoma; conservative management with regular monitoring.

options.label: D
options.text: Inflammatory carcinoma; urgent biopsy and treatment.

questions.correct_answer: B. Fibroadenoma; conservative management with regular monitoring.
questions.explanation:
Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumors arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast"

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring

(Option B)

  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision (Option C)

Prognosis
  • Benign, do not increase risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas

questions.text: A 34 y/o woman presents with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels following a molar pregnancy. Imaging studies reveal no evidence of metastases. What is the most appropriate initial chemotherapy regimen for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Risk Category

Treatment Approach

Low-Risk GTN
  • Chemotherapy: Methotrexate (MTX) alone or with folinic acid
  • Alternative Chemotherapy: Dactinomycin for MTX-resistant cases. (Option C)

High-Risk GTN
  • Chemotherapy Regimens: EMA/CO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine).
  • Alternative Regimens:
    • EMA/EP (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Etoposide, Cisplatin)
    • TP/TE (Paclitaxel, Cisplatin alternating with Paclitaxel, Etoposide) (Option A)
    • BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin) (Option B)
